chapter.title: The Projects and Lines tab
chapter.para: Projects and lines are the organizer entities (see Projects, lines and flows). They are created and managed in the Projects and Lines tab. Lines are grouped in projects, for sake of organization. The information presented in the Flows tab depends on the line selected at the moment.

mediaobject.caption: Screenshot of the Projects and Lines tab. The right-hand side of the screen shows the details of the selected item, like its name, description and creation date.

tip.para: Try using a context menu instead of the buttons on the toolbar. To do so, right-click on one of the projects or lines which has already been created. Notice that many commands can be found in this context menu. For certain cases this method is even easier and faster then using the toolbar buttons.

section.title: Creating projects and lines
section.para: The button creates a project. The title and description of the project, besides user's email are asked during this action. This basic information can be further edited through the edit button .

The project will appear on the left side of the window (see Figure). Information about the project is shown on the right hand side of GêBR's main window. Note that some of this information comes from what was previously specified. Details such as creation date and modified date are automatically generated by GêBR.

The button
creates a line. The information below will be requested to complete this operation:

listitem.para: Basic properties of the line: title, description, author, and e-mail address (they can be further edited through the button );

section.para: An assistant dialog will guide the user through the setup of a line. When the assistant is completed, the line will be created and shown as part of the selected project. Like the project's settings, the line's settings are exhibited on the right side of GêBR's window.
To create lines, GêBR must be connected to a domain (see ). This is mandatory since the all paths created at that moment should be in the file system of the processing nodes of a connected domain.

section.title: Deleting projects and lines
section.para:
To delete a line, select it and then left-click on
. A dialog will pop up to confirm this operation. A checkbox in that dialog allows the user to instruct the GêBR to delete all files in the BASE path of the line.

warning.para: When a line is deleted all its flows are also deleted. This operation cannot be undone.

section.para: To delete a project, it must not contain lines, so it is necessary to delete them first, and then proceed to the project. This is a protection to avoid miss-clicking the delete button.

section.title: Important folders of a line
section.para: GêBR defines a directory structure to aid in the task of managing the data associated to a set of flows. This structure is defined by a top directory, known as BASEBASE, and few other nested standard directories. They are:

tr.td: is the top directory where most of the files referred in the line should be. All directories below are nested in the BASE.
is the suggested directory to store all intermediate data files produced during the processing of the line.
is the suggested directory to keep temporary and disposable files.
is the suggested directory to place exporting data, not suitable to futher processing, like figures.
is the suggested directory to store tabular data.
is employed to store files at convenience of the user.

section.para: Other important folder is the HOME, which is is automatically set to the path of the user's home directory.

For instance, suppose we are going to set the important folders of a line. If the user's home folder is /home/john/, the BASE path must be set inside /home/john/. Taking this into consideration, and setting the BASE path to /home/john/GeBR/MyFirstLine/, this is going to be the directory structure associated to the line:
This standard directory structure eases the task of managing data related to lines (see ).

important.para: Remember that the processing takes place at the processing nodeProcessing nodes. The directory structure described above will be created there. This means that these directories will not be present on the local machine if the processing nodes and the client machine (where GêBR interface is running) do not pertain to the same domain.
To be able to browse files in these directories, the remote browseRemote browsing feature must be enabled in the domainDomain of the line (see ).

note.para: Although it is not mandatory to adhere to this structure, it is highly recommended to do so. That is, it is advantageous to place input and output files of flows in the paths described above.

section.title: Changing the domain of a line
section.para: GêBR supports only one connected domainDomain at once. However, there may be several domains available, one domain for Lab A and another for Lab B, for example.

Whenever GêBR is connected to one specific domain, all lines belonging to other domains won't be available for edition. However, a line can be migrated from its original domain to the connected domain. To do so, the line must be selected. In the right-hand side panel, an icon in the upper left corner indicates whether the domain of the line is connected or not. In case the original domain is not connected, by clicking over that icon, GêBR will offer two options:

listitem.para: disconnect from current domain and connect to the domain associated to the line; or
dissociate the line from its original domain and associate it to connected domain.

important.para: Whenever a line is migrated from one domain to another, all data in the BASEBASE directory and in its children will remain in the nodes of the original domain. That is, the data inside BASE path of the line is not automatically migrated.

section.title: Exporting and importing projects or lines
section.para: Although GêBR continuously saves all data, sometimes it is desirable to have copies of projects and/or lines in a file (for example, to share them with others or to make backups). To export a project or a line:

step.para: Select the line or project that that will be saved;
A dialog will be shown. Choose a directory and a name for the file;
Left-click on the Save button to conclude the export.

tip.para: GêBR determines the extension automatically, i.e., .prjx for projects and .lnex for lines.

section.para: To import projects or lines that were previously exported follow the steps:

step.para: Select the desired project or line to import in the dialog that appeared. Only files with extension prjz, prjx, lnez or lnex will be shown;

section.para: An imported project is added to the list of projects, while an imported line joins the other lines of project that was selected prior to this process. In both cases the imported item is identified with the suffix Imported.

note.para: In GêBR, lines may only exist inside a project (see ). Therefore to import a line one has to first select an existing project, or create a new one.

section.title: Report of a project or a line
section.para: Projects and lines can be commented and have an automatic report Reportof a project Reportof a line generation. To edit their commentaries, follow the steps:

step.para: Click on the More button on the toolbar;
Fill in some comment in the text editor that is presented;
When finished, save and close the editor.

tip.para:
You can print the report by clicking
File Print

section.para:
The report can be visualized by clicking over
More View Report .

mediaobject.caption: The line report contains information concerning the associated flows and their programs, important folders and variables.

section.para: After clicking on View Report, a window will appear showing the generated report for that project or line. This window has some functionalities that are mentioned below:

listitem.para: Include comments for this line into the report;
Include the reports of all flow of this line;

menuchoice.guisubmenu: Include the report of the snapshots of flows;

listitem.para: This option will include reports from all snapshots of all the flows that compose this line (see );
Allows to choose how much information about the parameters will be shown.
Change the presentation style of the report.
